unnormalised: **Manufacturing & Supply Chain: Quality Control Focus Intensifies**
normalised: **manufacturing and supply chain: quality control focus intensifies**

unnormalised: Gurgaon, Haryana - Amidst growing concerns over product integrity, manufacturers across India are placing renewed emphasis on quality control measures. This comes after a series of product recalls that have shaken consumer confidence, especially in the automotive and electronics sectors.
normalised: gurgaon, haryana - amidst growing concerns over product integrity, manufacturers across india are placing renewed emphasis on quality control measures. this comes after a series of product recalls that have shaken consumer confidence, especially in the automotive and electronics sectors.

unnormalised: Industry experts, like Dr. Sharma from IIT Delhi, suggest implementing stringent Six Sigma methodologies to minimize defects. He cited examples of successful quality control programs inspired by the dedication seen even in Bollywood films like "Chak De! India", where meticulous training and process focus led to victory.
normalised: industry experts, like doctor sharma from I I T delhi, suggest implementing stringent six sigma methodologies to minimize defects. he cited examples of successful quality control programs inspired by the dedication seen even in bollywood films like "chak de! india", where meticulous training and process focus led to victory.

unnormalised: Leading supply chain firms are investing in advanced technologies, including AI-powered inspection systems and blockchain-based traceability, to ensure transparency and accountability at every stage. Preliminary reports indicate that this enhanced focus has already reduced defects by approximately 15% in pilot programs. Rs. 5 crore has been allocated for training programs for QC personnel in the next financial year. The goal is to achieve a near-zero defect rate by 2025, boosting India's reputation as a global manufacturing hub. Manufacturers are also exploring collaborations with international standards organizations to benchmark their processes.
normalised: leading supply chain firms are investing in advanced technologies, including A I powered inspection systems and blockchain based traceability, to ensure transparency and accountability at every stage. preliminary reports indicate that this enhanced focus has already reduced defects by approximately fifteen percent in pilot programs. rupee five crore has been allocated for training programs for Q C personnel in the next financial year. the goal is to achieve a near zero defect rate by two thousand and twenty five, boosting india's reputation as a global manufacturing hub. manufacturers are also exploring collaborations with international standards organizations to benchmark their processes.
